explanation:
The correct calculation uses the conversion \(1\ \mathrm{L} = 1000\ \mathrm{cm}^3\), giving \(4 \times 1000 = 4000\). The student multiplied \(4 \times 10 = 40\), suggesting they used a linear conversion factor of 10 instead of the cubed factor. 

The error stems from treating volume conversion as a linear measurement. The student likely knew \(1\ \mathrm{dm} = 10\ \mathrm{cm}\) but failed to cube this ratio when converting \(1\ \mathrm{L} (=1\ \mathrm{dm}^3)\) to \(\mathrm{cm}^3\). This caused them to use \(10\) instead of \(10^3 = 1000\). 

This directly aligns with the "does not cube the conversion factor" misconception. It differs from the "thinks \(1\ \mathrm{L} = 100\ \mathrm{cm}^3\)" error, which would produce \(400\), not \(40\). The student's specific miscalculation shows they recognized a unit relationship but neglected its three-dimensional nature.
